newsitem.title: SOUTH KOREA: PRESS DIGEST - S.Korean newspapers - Nov 1.
newsitem.headline: PRESS DIGEST - S.Korean newspapers - Nov 1.

text.p: The following is a summary of major South Korean political stories in leading newspapers, prepared by Reuters in Seoul. Reuters has not checked the stories and does not gaurantee their accuracy. Telephone: (822) 727-5650. Fax: (822) 727-5666.
- Seoul city government studies a plan to lower intra-city bus fares in wake of an embezzlment scandal involving 17 bus company owners.

- Former president Choi Kyu-hah expected to be forced to testify in appeal trial session involving ex-presidents Chun and Roh, who have been sentenced to death and life term on treason and rebellion charges, respectively. Choi, considered a key figure who witnessed the turbulent developments during the 1979 military coup and bloody crackdown, has consistently refused to testify on the case.
- Korea becomes board member of the U.N. economic and social council by winning 128 votes in the second voting at the UN general assembly.
- Investigation begins against mid-level public servants involved in various irregularities.
- Gasoline price hiked to 730 won per liter from 711 won, effective today.
- Stability on Korean peninsula depends on reform in North Korea, said the chairman of the ruling New Korea Party.
- South Korea and the United States agree to quicken deployment of advanced arms to blunt North Korean threat.
